intro: Passerina linearis, commonly known as the slender pasqueflower, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of western North America. It belongs to the Ranunculaceae family and is characterized by its delicate, showy flowers that bloom in early spring. The plant typically grows in alpine and subalpine habitats, where it thrives in well-drained soils and full sunlight. Passerina linearis has a basal rosette of leaves that are linear and covered in fine hairs, and its flowers are usually pink or white with five sepals and numerous stamens. Due to its specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and endangered species in many areas.
